captions.text: It's bubbling. Bubbles are surfacing. Lots of bubbles!

That's from.. that's from the herring
It may get close to us.
This may be a close one. -It's bubbling everywhere now
This may be a close one.
I don't want to be closer than that. -[swearing]

comments.author: Christian Andersen

comments.text:
The discussion on animal hunting is telling me people are really uneducated 
about the topic. There is undercover proof that has shown time and time 
again that animals are never killed humanely in slaughter houses. 
Supposedly humane bolt gun is not so humane after all. It has been proven 
that the slaughterers use the bolt gun in adequately. The workers kill so 
many animals, they don't put any effort to comfort the animal. They usually 
discharge the gun in the wrong place. Some animals just stay conscious even 
after being shot. Other slaughter houses don't even try to stun the animal. 
They tie or bind the head in a stretched position and slit the throat. 
These animals are transported in double decker trucks where they trample 
each other and break legs. They then have to wait in a small and cramped 
corral until it is time to be killed. Many animals are not fed or watered 
while waiting to die. They can smell the blood of others and can hear 
strange machinery. Many slaughter animals were once treated with at least 
some respect. Now they are prodded with electric pig prods and are hit with 
metal rods. In some slaughter houses, horses are incapacitated by jabbing a 
knife into the general spine area. This does not kill the animal. The 
throat slitting does that. Even a stunned animal wakes up as its throat is 
slit. They thrash in agony as the blood drains out of the cut and the mouth 
and nose. Ocean mammals are killed viciously. Sometimes they are stabbed 
until the spine is hit, they have their throats slit, etc. Dolphins and 
whales are intelligent creatures that have more empathy that we will ever 
have. They feel pain just like us. Perhaps even more so. We destroy the 
oceans by polluting them and to add to that, we brutalize the animals. What 
does that tell you about the human race? ﻿

comments.author: HorizonExer

comments.text:
+Magnus Hans Petersson
 
I think we're all aware of the 'anything goes' fishing policies of the 
Japanese and others, specifically so certain products can be hyped as 
genuine whale sourced for the niche and millionaire markets, underground 
collectors and consumers, and the rather shady world of illegal trade of 
banned animal products for medicine.
 
Lots of animal species should be protected, specifically because they 
cannot be farmed for food and because their existence should not be seen as 
merely the means by which we support our own.
 
If my opinion rankles some observers, well, I'll just have to try and live 
with that, won't I? .
comments.author: GinSkimPivot

comments.text:
Marine mammals are humanely killed quickly and the process is monitored and 
legislated. Whale meat in Scandinavia is normal food, even cheaper than 
beef, not some "non-essential luxury item". And they don't hunt the species 
in this video, cause those are protected.
comments.author: Scandinavian Cinema Reviews

comments.text:
+HorizonExer
 
*"But hurt a not so beautiful aminal like a cow or a sheep is ok. The 
double moral with people like you is disgusting."*
 
Self-defeating outburst.
 
Farmed animals are humanely killed quickly and their breeding and 
processing is legislated and monitored. They also tend not to be required 
for non-essential luxury items and whimsical products or hunted down to die 
lingering painful deaths.
 
What double moral?

I think all animals are beautiful, none more so than the commonest 
species that sustain and enhance our well-being. These creatures are rare 
and their culling and processing is entirely unnecessary.
comments.author: GinSkimPivot

comments.text: +HorizonExer the numbers in species are even comparable.
comments.author: Mazwell96

comments.text:
But hurt a not so beautiful aminal like a cow or a sheep is ok. The double 
moral with people like you is disgusting.
comments.author: HorizonExer

comments.text:
+Caroline Burton Well we don't hunt the humpback whale you see in the 
video, only the minke whale, the yearly quota is 523 animals I beleive but 
rarely are more then 42 animals caught each year if I remember right, it is 
mostly done cause the minke whale eats so much that it might unbalance the 
area it feeds in, but yeah whale meat is pretty expensive and not to common 
 many places, the japanese are alot worse then us.
comments.author: Frisky Hunter

comments.text:
+Caroline Burton No they don't, cause humpback whales are protected. The 
ONLY species hunted is small and non-endangered, abundant minke whales, and 
in fairly small amounts by shore based, small sustainable fisheries. 
Beautiful creatures, but so are other animals as well. Minke whale meat 
tastes really sweet, I live in Sweden but I go over the border to Norway 
sometimes and buys minke whale meat, its almost like moose meat. But I 
would never eat somethings thats endangered like humpback whales, and 
luckily those aren't hunted either.
comments.author: Scandinavian Cinema Reviews

comments.author: joey

comments.text:
I'm in Indiana and I've been whale watching 2 times in my life. Don't be 
afraid to go out on vacation and make it part of your trip! The first was 
whale watching in Seattle for orcas on my birthday. The second was in 
Boston for humpbacks when I went to see a concert for my brother. It's an 
amazing experience and you won't regret it.

Киты-шутники, или Как застать человека врасплох

одновременно всплыли на поверхность около лодки, перепугав одного из 
рыбаков.
